question: Question_05_(b)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problems}. In questions 5-11, justify your answers
and \textbf{show all your work}. If a box is provided, write your final
answer there. \textbf{Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of
numerical answers is required in these questions.}

5. A sample of the radioactive substance Rhodium-101 decayed to 12.5\%
of its original amount after 10 years.

(b) What is the half-life of Rhodium-101? Remember to simplify your
answer completely.
sols:
From part a, we know that

$\displaystyle y(t) = 100e^{t\ln(1/8)/10} = 100e^{\ln((1/8)^{t/10})} = 100(1/8)^{t/10}$

Writing as a power of 1/2, we have

$\displaystyle y(t) = 100(1/8)^{t/10} = 100(1/2^{3})^{t/10} = 100(1/2)^{3t/10}$

In order for the rightmost expression to give us \emph{50}, the exponent
needs to equal \emph{1}. Thus, the value of \emph{t} that gives
$\displaystyle y(t) = 50$ is $\displaystyle  t = 10/3$

From part a, we have

$\displaystyle y(t) = 100e^{t\ln(1/8)/10} = 100e^{\ln((1/8)^{t/10})} = 100(1/8)^{t/10}$

Because \emph{y(t)} represents the percentage of Rhodium-101 remaining
at time \emph{t}, to find half-life (which is when there is 50\%
remaining), we set $y(t) = 50$ and solve for \emph{t}.

\begin{align*}
50 &= 100(1/8)^{t/10} \\
1/2 &= (1/8)^{t/10} \\
1/2 &= (1/2^{3})^{t/10} \\
1/2 &= (1/2)^{3t/10} \\
1 &= \frac{3t}{10} \\
\frac{10}{3} &= t
\end{align*}

completing the question.
